channel.title: Blu tack as a thermal compound?
channel.description:
My router's overheating and keeps crashing because of this shitty weather. I've put a heatsink and fan on the main chip, but it isn't cooling it down that well because the heatsink isn't in 100% contact with the chip. I have no thermal compound as I've never needed it before and need a quick fix to stop my router dieing. I can always go out and get some real paste in a few days, and sort out a good cooling system for it.
So yeah, would blu tack work as at least a half decent thermal compound, or would it insulate the chip more than conducting the heat away?

item.title: Blu tack as a thermal compound?
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

i thought that density is generally proportional to thermal conductivity. my spit is more dense than blu tack, so you are probably correct. the problem lies with the fact that it is a liquid and would simply evaporate or run off the chip.

Read full topic

item.title: Blu tack as a thermal compound?
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

But why would blu-tack help? Your spit would have a better chance conducting heat away from the CPU into the heat-sink.

Read full topic

item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

sanga282:

yeah xEnt am going to, just need some more thermal compound was thinking about getting a H50 or a CoolIT ALC however i cbf to remove my mobo to access the underside of the CPU socket

H50 is worth it, I gave ocing my Q6600 a shot, it wouldn’t reach 50c under prime95 with voltages up to 1.4(cpuz was reporting 1.2-1.3), but when I run it stock it won’t reach 40c under prime95.

Read full topic

item.source: Blu tack as a thermal compound?

item.title: Blu tack as a thermal compound?
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

[quote=“sppt, post:21, topic:341148”][quote author=sanga282 link=topic=437545.msg3216301#msg3216301 date=1274706553]

I’m using the thermal compound that came with the i7 cooler, overclocked the BCLK to 166, and it averages 44-45 degrees when idle.
Don’t see why I should apply different thermal paste.

my i7 runs stupidly hot for some reason, i’ve got a custom cooler, a big fuck off massive one and some decent thermal compound and OC was at 3.4Ghz with a core voltage of 1.225 and was still getting it idling at like 70sih i’ve lowered the voltage down to default again and have my clock sitting at 3Ghz still looking at like 50-60 idle temps, what voltages have you got for yours?
[/quote]
Stock voltages. The only thing I changed was the BCLK frequency with 33mhz.
It’s actually getting hot outside, and right now my idle temps are 45-48 celcius.[/quote]
orly, i’ve got my IOH voltage bolstered and my DRAM, what speed where you getting with 166? around 3.3ish? i was getting 3.4 with 170 BCLCK and QPI multiplier of 20

Read full topic
